natural solution: This 4-term geometric series has first term $a_0 = \frac13$ and ratio $r=\frac13$, so it has value  \begin{align} \dfrac{\dfrac13\left(1-\left(\dfrac13\right)^{4}\right)}{1-\frac13} &= \dfrac{\dfrac13(1-\left(\dfrac13\right)^{4})}{\dfrac23}\\

a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of $\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right) + \left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^2 + \left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^3 + \left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^4$? The final Answer is \dfrac{40}{81}
 ### Proof
 This 4-term geometric series has first term $a_0 = \frac13$ and ratio $r=\frac13$, so it has value  \begin{align} \dfrac{\dfrac13\left(1-\left(\dfrac13\right)^{4}\right)}{1-\frac13} &= \dfrac{\dfrac13(1-\left(\dfrac13\right)^{4})}{\dfrac23}\\
 &=\dfrac12\left(1-\left(\dfrac13\right)^{4}\right)\\ &=\dfrac12\left(\dfrac{80}{81}\right)\\ &=\boxed{\dfrac{40}{81}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
shows  "1/3 + (1/3) powr 2 + (1/3) powr 3 + (1/3) powr 4 = 40 / 81"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the sum of $\frac{1}{3}$, $\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^2$, $\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^3$, and $\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^4$. The final answer is $\frac{40}{81}$.

 &=\dfrac12\left(1-\left(\dfrac13\right)^{4}\right)\\ &=\dfrac12\left(\dfrac{80}{81}\right)\\ &=\boxed{\dfrac{40}{81}}. \end{align}
 *)
